title: Example analysis
text:
Question: How do penguin body size metrics (e.g.¬†flipper length and body mass) vary across species and sex?
Intended audience: Readers who want a quick, visual overview of species-level differences‚Äîstudents learning data viz and anyone curious about Antarctic penguins.
Dataset: This analysis uses the palmerpenguins dataset Horst, Hill, and Gorman (2024a), which provides an alternative to the classic ‚Äúiris‚Äù dataset for demonstrating tidy data principles.


This dataset contains 344 penguins from the Palmer Archipelago, with measurements such as flipper length, bill size, and body mass.
The dataset comes from the palmerpenguins R package by Allison Horst, Alison Hill, and Kristen Gorman (Horst, Hill, and Gorman 2024a, 2024b).
- Overview: palmerpenguins vignette (Horst, Hill, and Gorman 2024b)
- CRAN Reference Manual (data dictionary): palmerpenguins.pdf (Horst, Hill, and Gorman 2024a)
- Alternative data dictionary (web article): RPubs data dictionary (Iannone 2021)






Note



Image requirement.
Below we include an external image from the palmerpenguins artwork collection (credit: Allison Horst).
If desired, you can download it and save locally under images/.

title: Example analysis
text:
Question: How do penguin body size metrics (e.g.¬†flipper length and body mass) vary across species and sex?
Intended audience: Readers who want a quick, visual overview of species-level differences‚Äîstudents learning data viz and anyone curious about Antarctic penguins.
Dataset: This analysis uses the palmerpenguins dataset Horst, Hill, and Gorman (2024a), which provides an alternative to the classic ‚Äúiris‚Äù dataset for demonstrating tidy data principles.


This dataset contains 344 penguins from the Palmer Archipelago, with measurements such as flipper length, bill size, and body mass.
The dataset comes from the palmerpenguins R package by Allison Horst, Alison Hill, and Kristen Gorman (Horst, Hill, and Gorman 2024a, 2024b).
- Overview: palmerpenguins vignette (Horst, Hill, and Gorman 2024b)
- CRAN Reference Manual (data dictionary): palmerpenguins.pdf (Horst, Hill, and Gorman 2024a)
- Alternative data dictionary (web article): RPubs data dictionary (Iannone 2021)






Note



Image requirement.
Below we include an external image from the palmerpenguins artwork collection (credit: Allison Horst).
If desired, you can download it and save locally under images/.

title: Example analysis
text:
Data Analysis

Load packages and dataset

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyr)
library(palmerpenguins)

peng <- penguins
head(peng)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 8
  species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195        3250
4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA          NA
5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>




Data Wrangling
We first clean and summarize the dataset by removing missing values and grouping by species and sex. We cite packages used for wrangling and plots (Wickham et al. (2025); Wickham (2016)).

peng_clean <-
  peng %>%
  drop_na(species, sex, body_mass_g, flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm) %>% # tidyr::drop_na
  mutate(
    body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000,
    sex = factor(sex, levels = c("female", "male"))
  ) %>%                             
  select(species, island, sex, bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm, flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g, body_mass_kg) %>% 
  arrange(species, sex) %>%     
  group_by(species, sex) %>%     
  summarise(
    n = dplyr::n(),
    mean_mass_kg = mean(body_mass_kg, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_flipper = mean(flipper_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )                                   

peng_long <-
  peng %>%
  drop_na(body_mass_g, flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(body_mass_g, flipper_length_mm, bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm),
    names_to = "measure", values_to = "value"
  )                                      







Tip



Tip. If your render fails, make sure you‚Äôve installed the packages: install.packages(c(‚Äúpalmerpenguins‚Äù,‚Äúdplyr‚Äù,‚Äútidyr‚Äù,‚Äúggplot2‚Äù)).




Plot 1 ‚Äî Flipper vs.¬†body mass (faceted scatter)

ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  facet_wrap(~ species, nrow = 1) +
  labs(
    title = "Penguin body mass increases with flipper length",
    subtitle = "Linear trends by species | Palmer Archipelago (Antarctica)",
    x = "Flipper length (mm)",
    y = "Body mass (g)",
    caption = "Data: palmerpenguins package"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12)










Plot 2 ‚Äî Body mass by species & sex (boxplot)

peng_box <- penguins %>% tidyr::drop_na(species, sex, body_mass_g)

ggplot(peng_box, aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g, fill = sex)) +
  geom_boxplot(outlier.alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(
    title = "Body mass distribution by species and sex",
    subtitle = "Heavier Gentoo on average; sex differences visible within species",
    x = "Species",
    y = "Body mass (g)",
    caption = "Data: palmerpenguins"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12)










Plot 3 ‚Äî Mean size summary (column chart)

ggplot(peng_clean, aes(x = species, y = mean_flipper, fill = sex)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  labs(
    title = "Average flipper length by species and sex",
    subtitle = "Summary after grouping and summarising",
    x = "Species",
    y = "Mean flipper length (mm)",
    caption = "Computed from cleaned data"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12)










Result Summary
Across the three penguin species, body mass shows a clear positive relationship with flipper length, as visualized by the linear trends in the faceted scatterplot. Gentoo penguins are generally the heaviest and have the longest flippers, while Adelie and Chinstrap penguins are smaller in both dimensions. The boxplot reveals that males tend to be heavier than females within each species, indicating a consistent sex-based difference in body size. The bar chart further confirms that Gentoo penguins have the largest mean flipper length overall. Together, these findings highlight distinct morphological variations across species and sex, reflecting adaptations to their respective ecological niches.
Together, these findings highlight distinct morphological differences across species and sex, reflecting evolutionary adaptations to their ecological environments.


Function Checklist

Data wrangling with dplyr and tidyr:

drop_na()
mutate()
select()
arrange()
group_by()
summarise()
pivot_longer()
n()

Data visualization with ggplot2:

ggplot()
geom_point()
geom_smooth()
facet_wrap()
geom_boxplot()
geom_col()
labs()
theme_minimal()
aes()

title: Home
text:
Hi, I‚Äôm Yuxun He üëã
I‚Äôm a master student in Biostatistics at Johns Hopkins University.
In my free time, I enjoy hiking, playing snooker and badminton, and exploring computer games‚Äîthey help me stay balanced and creative beyond studying.





This is my personal website built with Quarto.

title: About
text:
Education
I received my Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Environmental Science and Engineering from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in China, where I developed a strong foundation in environmental modeling and data analysis. Currently, I am pursuing a Master‚Äôs degree in Biostatistics at Johns Hopkins University, focusing on the integration of statistical and machine learning approaches for biomedical and genomic research.


Research Interest
I am passionate about machine learning (ML) and its interdisciplinary applications, particularly in biology and genomics. Specifically, my previous work has involved diffusion models, statistical learning, and computational genomics, where I explored how data-driven models can enhance biological interpretability and improve predictive performance.
